title: Establishes the offense of aggravated criminal conduct as a class E felony
summary: Establishes the offense of aggravated criminal conduct, when a person commits a misdemeanor after having been previously convicted of six or more qualifying misdemeanor or felony crimes within the preceding year, as a class E felony.

BILL NUMBER:S1512

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the penal law, in relation to aggravated criminal conduct

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1: Adds a new Penal Law section 240.75 to create the crime of
aggravated criminal conduct. A person is guilty of aggravated
criminal conduct when he or she commits a qualifying misdemeanor, as
specified in this section, after having previously committed six or
more such qualifying misdemeanors, or felonies, within the previous
year. The punishment for aggravated criminal conduct is a Class E
Felony.

Subdivision (2) of this new section would provide that the provisions
of Criminal Procedure Law section 200.60, which prohibits allegations
of previous convictions in indictments for an offense where such
convictions are elements of the offense, shall apply to any
prosecutions for aggravated criminal conduct. Section 200.60 provides
a procedure for allowing defendants to admit their previous
conviction{s} in the absence of the jury, in which case the
prosecution may not prove the fact of the previous conviction{s} to
the jury. The application of CPL section 200.60 to the offense of
aggravated criminal conduct will help protect defendants from
potential prejudice by jurors on account of their previous
convictions.

This new Penal Law section would also require that all previous
convictions must have been in New York courts and that defendants
have had their sentences imposed before commission of the present
misdemeanor. Suspended sentences, suspended executions of sentences,
probation, parole, and conditional and unconditional discharges are
deemed to be sentences, but reversed, vacated, or pardoned
convictions will not be deemed previous convictions. Multiple
sentences for two or more convictions that were imposed at the same
time are deemed to constitute only one conviction. Previous
convictions already used to convict a defendant of this offense shall
not be used to establish guilt for a subsequent prosecution for
aggravated criminal conduct. Finally, in calculating the one-year
period, any period of time during which the defendant was
incarcerated for any reason between the time of sentence for any of
the previous convictions and the time of commission of the present
misdemeanor will be excluded.

Section 2 would make this bill effective immediately.

JUSTIFICATION:
This bill is intended to assist law enforcement to effectively
prosecute and sentence repeat misdemeanants, a class of career
criminals for which current penalties are ineffective in deterring a
continued life of crime. This small number of criminals is
disproportionately responsible for a large number of crimes. The
current Penal Law does not contain sufficient penalties for
individuals who Continue to commit crimes without the fear of any
serious repercussions.


This new crime of aggravated criminal conduct would allow law
enforcement to prosecute and sentence repeat misdemeanor offenders
who are disproportionately responsible for a large number of
quality-of-life crimes. For instance, in New York City in 2007, there
were 551 offenders with seven or more qualifying criminal convictions
in the course of the year - a total of 4,542 convictions among them.
Although these individuals only made up 0.8% of all offenders, they
accounted for 4.3% of total convictions and some have rap sheets over
twenty-five pages long.
This small group of high-rate serial misdemeanants has a disparate
impact on quality of life in the city and often receives little to no
punishment. By allowing prosecutors to prosecute persistent
misdemeanants as felons, this law provides law enforcement with the
ability to target career criminals who continue to commit crimes with
impunity.

This bill was submitted by the City of New York and the Mayor of New
York urges that this bill be enacted into law during the 2010
Legislative session.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
Immediate.
